          V-204599 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon does not permit Kerberos authentication unless needed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204599r853994_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040440
          Identities:V-72261
          SV-86885
          CCI-000318 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-3 e; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-3.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-3 f; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-3 f)
          CCI-000368 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 c; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 c; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 c)
          CCI-001812 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-11 (2))
          CCI-001813 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-5 (1) (a))
          CCI-001814 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-5 (1))
          Description: Kerberos authentication for SSH is often implemented using Generic Security Service Application Program Interface (GSSAPI). If Kerberos is enabled through SSH, the SSH daemon provides a means of access to the system's Kerberos implementation. Vulnerabilities in the system's Kerberos implementation may then be subject to exploitation. To reduce the attack surface of the system, the Kerberos authentication mechanism within SSH must be disabled for systems not using this capability. false
          Fix Text:Uncomment the "KerberosAuthentication" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "no":

          KerberosAuthentication no

          The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.

          If Kerberos authentication is required, it must be documented, to include the location of the configuration file, with the ISSO.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:162
          Result:false
          Title:Disable Kerberos Authentication
          Description:Unless needed, disable the Kerberos authentication option for the SSH Server.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (tests the value of KerberosAuthentication setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (package openssh-server is removed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:163 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:tests the value of KerberosAuthentication setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2100 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*(?i)KerberosAuthentication(?-i)[\s]+(\w+)[\s]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8688500 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'no'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1269 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:false
          Title:package openssh-server is removed
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          V-204600 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon performs strict mode checking of home directory configuration files.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204600r603261_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040450
          Identities:SV-86887
          V-72263
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: If other users have access to modify user-specific SSH configuration files, they may be able to log on to the system as another user. false
          Fix Text:Uncomment the "StrictModes" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "yes":

          StrictModes yes

          The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0

          Publisher:DISA

          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (tests the value of StrictModes setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (package openssh-server is removed)

          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*(?i)StrictModes(?-i)[\s]+(\w+)[\s]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

          V-204601 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that the SSH daemon uses privilege separation.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204601r603261_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040460
          Identities:SV-86889
          V-72265
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: SSH daemon privilege separation causes the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed, which would decrease the impact of software vulnerabilities in the unprivileged section. false
          Fix Text:Uncomment the "UsePrivilegeSeparation" keyword in "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor) and set the value to "sandbox" or "yes":

          UsePrivilegeSeparation sandbox

          The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:171
          Result:false
          Title:Use Privilege Separation
          Description:Use privilege separation to cause the SSH process to drop root privileges when not needed.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (tests the value of UsePrivilegeSeparation setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (package openssh-server is removed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:172 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:tests the value of UsePrivilegeSeparation setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:One or more item-state comparisons may be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2105 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*(?i)UsePrivilegeSeparation(?-i)[\s]+(\w+)[\s]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8688900 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'sandbox'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8688901 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'yes'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1269 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:false
          Title:package openssh-server is removed
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          • name must be equal to 'openssh-server'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]

          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'

          • extended_name equals 'openssh-server-(none):7.4p1-21.el7.x86_64'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204613 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not respond to Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204613r880809_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040630
          Identities:V-72287
          SV-86911
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Responding to broadcast (ICMP) echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks. false
          Fix Text:Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):

          net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts = 1

          Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:

          # sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:284
          Result:false
          Title:Kernel "net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts" Parameter Configuration and Runtime Check
          Description:The "net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts" kernel parameter should be set to the appropriate value in both system configuration and system runtime.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts static configuration)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts set to the appropriate value)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:399 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts static configuration
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:20461300 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2280 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:332 (sysctl_test)
          Result:true
          Title:kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts set to the appropriate value
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2191 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2192 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • for check = 'all', value, the following must be true:
            • value must be equal to '1'

          V-204614 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204614r880812_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040640
          Identities:SV-86913
          V-72289
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack. false
          Fix Text:Set the system to not accept IPv4 ICMP redirect messages by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):

          net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects = 0

          Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:

          # sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:266
          Result:false
          Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must prevent Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.
          Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0)
            • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in a configuration file in an acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and no conflicting configurations are in the files)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:326 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2179 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2180 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:375 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in a configuration file in an acceptable directory is set to 0, and nothing else, and no conflicting configurations are in the files
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2253 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2251 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204615 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must ignore Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204615r880815_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040641
          Identities:SV-87827
          V-73175
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack. false
          Fix Text:Set the system to ignore IPv4 ICMP redirect messages by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):

          net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects = 0

          Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:

          # sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:248
          Result:false
          Title:Kernel "net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects" Parameter Configuration and Runtime Check
          Description:The "net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects" kernel parameter should be set to the appropriate value in both system configuration and system runtime.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects static configuration)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects set to the appropriate value)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:351 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects static configuration
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:20461500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2256 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:320 (sysctl_test)

          V-204616 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not allow interfaces to perform Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects by default.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204616r880818_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040650
          Identities:V-72291
          SV-86915
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system to not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects by default.

          Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):

          net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0

          Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:

          # sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:281
          Result:false
          Title:Kernel "net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects" Parameter Configuration and Runtime Check
          Description:The "net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects" kernel parameter should be set to the appropriate value in both system configuration and system runtime.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects static configuration)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects set to 0)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:395 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects static configuration
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:20461600 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:20461600 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:331 (sysctl_test)

          Title:kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects set to 0
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2189 (sysctl_object)

          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects'

          V-204617 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not send Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204617r880821_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040660
          Identities:V-72293
          SV-86917
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system to not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects.

          Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):

          net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects = 0

          Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:

          # sysctl --system

          V-204622 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that remote X connections are disabled except to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204622r603849_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040710
          Identities:SV-86927
          V-72303
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The security risk of using X11 forwarding is that the client's X11 display server may be exposed to attack when the SSH client requests forwarding. A system administrator may have a stance in which they want to protect clients that may expose themselves to attack by unwittingly requesting X11 forwarding, which can warrant a ''no'' setting.
          X11 forwarding should be enabled with caution. Users with the ability to bypass file permissions on the remote host (for the user's X11 authorization database) can access the local X11 display through the forwarded connection. An attacker may then be able to perform activities such as keystroke monitoring if the ForwardX11Trusted option is also enabled.
          If X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the systems needs. false
          Fix Text:Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "X11Forwarding" keyword and set its value to "no" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):

          X11Forwarding no

          The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect:

          # systemctl restart sshd
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1389
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-07-040710 - Disable X11 Forwarding
          Description:Open X displays allow an attacker to capture keystrokes and execute commands remotely.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (tests the value of X11Forwarding setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (package openssh-server is removed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1390 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:tests the value of X11Forwarding setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3068 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • behavior requirements:
            • ignore_case = true
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*X11Forwarding[ \t]+([^\s#]*)[ \t]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:138900 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(no|"no")$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • path equals '/etc/ssh'
          • filename equals 'sshd_config'
          • pattern equals '^[\s]*X11Forwarding[ \t]+([^\s#]*)[ \t]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'X11Forwarding yes'
          • line equals 'X11Forwarding yes'
          • subexpression equals 'yes'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1269 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:false
          Title:package openssh-server is removed
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2994 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'openssh-server'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'openssh-server'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '21.el7'
          • version equals '7.4p1'
          • evr equals '0:7.4p1-21.el7'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'openssh-server-(none):7.4p1-21.el7.x86_64'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204625 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must not be performing packet forwarding unless the system is a router.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204625r880824_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040740
          Identities:SV-86933
          V-72309
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network. false
          Fix Text:Set the system to the required kernel parameter by adding the following line to "/etc/sysctl.conf" or a configuration file in the /etc/sysctl.d/ directory (or modify the line to have the required value):

          net.ipv4.ip_forward = 0

          Issue the following command to make the changes take effect:

          # sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:290
          Result:false
          Title:Kernel "net.ipv4.ip_forward" Parameter Configuration and Runtime Check
          Description:The "net.ipv4.ip_forward" kernel parameter should be set to the appropriate value in both system configuration and system runtime.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv4.ip_forward static configuration)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.ip_forward set to 0)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:407 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.ip_forward static configuration
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:20462500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2256 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          Title:kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.ip_forward set to 0

          V-204631 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must have the required packages for multifactor authentication installed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204631r853997_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-041001
          Identities:SV-87041
          V-72417
          CCI-001948 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (11))
          CCI-001953 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
          CCI-001954 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
          Description: Using an authentication device, such as a CAC or token that is separate from the information system, ensures that even if the information system is compromised, that compromise will not affect credentials stored on the authentication device.

          Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD Common Access Card.

          A privileged account is defined as an information system account with authorizations of a privileged user.

          Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

          This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). This does not apply to authentication for the purpose of configuring the device itself (management).

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00160, SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00161, SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00162 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to implement multifactor authentication by installing the required packages.

          Install the pam_pkcs11 package with the following command:

          # yum install pam_pkcs11
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:87041
          Result:false
          Title:The operating system must have the required packages for multifactor authentication installed.
          Description:The operating system must have the required packages for multifactor authentication installed.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (package 'pam_pkcs11' is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8704101 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:false
          Title:package 'pam_pkcs11' is installed
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8704101 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'pam_pkcs11'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204632 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement multifactor authentication for access to privileged accounts via pluggable authentication modules (PAM).

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204632r853998_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-041002
          Identities:V-72427
          SV-87051
          CCI-001948 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (11))
          CCI-001953 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
          CCI-001954 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
          Description: Using an authentication device, such as a CAC or token that is separate from the information system, ensures that even if the information system is compromised, that compromise will not affect credentials stored on the authentication device.

          Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD Common Access Card.

          A privileged account is defined as an information system account with authorizations of a privileged user.

          Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

          This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). This does not apply to authentication for the purpose of configuring the device itself (management).

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00160, SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00161, SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00162 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to implement multifactor authentication for remote access to privileged accounts via pluggable authentication modules (PAM).

          Modify all of the services lines in "/etc/sssd/sssd.conf" or in configuration files found under "/etc/sssd/conf.d" to include pam.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:

          Result:false
          Title:Configure PAM in SSSD Services
          Description:SSSD should be configured to run SSSD PAM services.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (check if pam is configured in the services setting of the sssd section)
            • false (check if pam is configured in the services setting of a conf file in the sssd conf.d directory)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1406 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:check if pam is configured in the services setting of the sssd section
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3081 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sssd/sssd.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*\[sssd\]([^\n]*\n+)+?[\s]*services.*pam.*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:140601 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:check if pam is configured in the services setting of a conf file in the sssd conf.d directory
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:140601 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/sssd/conf.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '^.*\.conf$'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*\[sssd\]([^\n]*\n+)+?[\s]*services.*pam.*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204633 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement certificate status checking for PKI authentication.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204633r853999_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-041003
          Identities:V-72433
          SV-87057
          CCI-001948 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (11))
          CCI-001953 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
          CCI-001954 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-2 (12); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-2 (12))
          Description: Using an authentication device, such as a CAC or token that is separate from the information system, ensures that even if the information system is compromised, that compromise will not affect credentials stored on the authentication device.

          Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD Common Access Card.

          A privileged account is defined as an information system account with authorizations of a privileged user.

          Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

          This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). This does not apply to authentication for the purpose of configuring the device itself (management).

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00160, SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00161, SRG-OS-000375-GPOS-00162 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to do certificate status checking for PKI authentication.

          Modify all of the "cert_policy" lines in "/etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf" to include "ocsp_on".
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:87057
          Result:false
          Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must implement certificate status checking for PKI authentication.
          Description:Using an authentication device, such as a CAC or token that is separate from the information system, ensures that even if the information system is compromised, that compromise will not affect credentials stored on the authentication device.

          Multifactor solutions that require devices separate from information systems gaining access include, for example, hardware tokens providing time-based or challenge-response authenticators and smart cards such as the U.S. Government Personal Identity Verification card and the DoD Common Access Card.

          A privileged account is defined as an information system account with authorizations of a privileged user.

          Remote access is access to DoD nonpublic information systems by an authorized user (or an information system) communicating through an external, non-organization-controlled network. Remote access methods include, for example, dial-up, broadband, and wireless.

          This requirement only applies to components where this is specific to the function of the device or has the concept of an organizational user (e.g., VPN, proxy capability). This does not apply to authentication for the purpose of configuring the device itself (management).
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Check all cert_policy entries are set with the ocsp_on option in /etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf)
            • false (Check cert_policy is set with the ocsp_on option 3 or more times in /etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8705700 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Check all cert_policy entries are set with the ocsp_on option in /etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8705700 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*cert_policy[ \t]+=[ \t]+([\w\,"' ]+);\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8705700 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^["']*ocsp_on["']*$|^["']*ocsp_on["',\s]|["',\s]ocsp_on["',\s]|["',\s]ocsp_on["']*$'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:8705701 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Check cert_policy is set with the ocsp_on option 3 or more times in /etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:8705701 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam_pkcs11/pam_pkcs11.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*cert_policy[ \t]+=[ \t]+([\w\,"' ]*ocsp_on[\w\,"' ]*);\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '3'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-237634 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo".

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-237634r880755_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-010342
          Identities:CCI-002227 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-6 (5); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-6 (5))
          Description: The sudoers security policy requires that users authenticate themselves before they can use sudo. When sudoers requires authentication, it validates the invoking user's credentials. If the rootpw, targetpw, or runaspw flags are defined and not disabled, by default the operating system will prompt the invoking user for the "root" user password.
          For more information on each of the listed configurations, reference the sudoers(5) manual page. false
          Fix Text:Define the following in the Defaults section of the /etc/sudoers file or a configuration file in the /etc/sudoers.d/ directory:
          Defaults !targetpw
          Defaults !rootpw
          Defaults !runaspw

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /etc/sudoers
          /etc/sudoers.d/
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:178
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-07-010342 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo".
          Description:The sudoers security policy requires that users authenticate themselves before they can use sudo. When sudoers requires authentication, it validates the invoking user's credentials. If the rootpw, targetpw, or runaspw flags are defined and not disabled, by default the operating system will prompt the invoking user for the "root" user password.
          For more information on each of the listed configurations, reference the sudoers(5) manual page.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers)
              • false (Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (Defaults !rootpw is configured in /etc/sudoers)
              • false (Defaults !rootpw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (Defaults !runaspw is configured in /etc/sudoers)
              • false (Defaults !runaspw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:17800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:17800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sudoers'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)Defaults\s+\!targetpw\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:17801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          • path must match the pattern '^/etc/sudoers\.d.*'

          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)Defaults\s+\!targetpw\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:17802 (textfilecontent54_test)

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:17802 (textfilecontent54_object)

          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sudoers'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)Defaults\s+\!rootpw\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-237635 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must require re-authentication when using the "sudo" command.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-237635r861075_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-010343
          Identities:CCI-002038 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-11)
          Description: Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

          When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the organization requires the user to re-authenticate when using the "sudo" command.

          If the value is set to an integer less than 0, the user's time stamp will not expire and the user will not have to re-authenticate for privileged actions until the user's session is terminated. false
          Fix Text:Configure the "sudo" command to require re-authentication.
          Edit the /etc/sudoers file:
          $ sudo visudo

          Add or modify the following line:
          Defaults timestamp_timeout=[value]
          Note: The "[value]" must be a number that is greater than or equal to "0".

          Remove any duplicate or conflicting lines from /etc/sudoers and /etc/sudoers.d/ files.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:179
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-07-010343 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must require re-authentication when using the "sudo" command.
          Description:Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

          When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the organization requires the user to re-authenticate when using the "sudo" command.

          If the value is set to an integer less than 0, the user's time stamp will not expire and the user will not have to re-authenticate for privileged actions until the user's session is terminated.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Defaults timestamp_timeout is configured in /etc/sudoers or /etc/sudoers.d/)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:17900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Defaults timestamp_timeout is configured in /etc/sudoers or /etc/sudoers.d/
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:17902 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:17900 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        Detailed Results: Low Severity (CAT III)

          V-204452 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204452r853894_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-020200
          Identities:V-71987
          SV-86611
          CCI-002617 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SI-2 (6); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SI-2 (6))
          Description: Previous versions of software components that are not removed from the information system after updates have been installed may be exploited by adversaries. Some information technology products may remove older versions of software automatically from the information system. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to remove all software components after updated versions have been installed.

          Set the "clean_requirements_on_remove" option to "1" in the "/etc/yum.conf" file:

          clean_requirements_on_remove=1
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:108
          Result:false
          Title:Ensure YUM Removes Previous Package Versions
          Description:The clean_requirements_on_remove option should be used to ensure that old
          versions of software components are removed after updating.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (check value of clean_requirements_on_remove in /etc/yum.conf)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:109 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:check value of clean_requirements_on_remove in /etc/yum.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2061 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/yum.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*clean_requirements_on_remove\s*=\s*(\S+)\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:2061 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(1|True|yes)$'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204493 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must be configured so that a separate file system is used for user home directories (such as /home or an equivalent).

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204493r603840_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-021310
          Identities:SV-86683
          V-72059
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
          Fix Text:Migrate the "/home" directory onto a separate file system/partition.
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1311
          Result:false
          Title:Ensure /home Located On Separate Partition
          Description:If user home directories will be stored locally, create a
          separate partition for /home. If /home will be mounted from another
          system such as an NFS server, then creating a separate partition is not
          necessary at this time, and the mountpoint can instead be configured
          later.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/home on own partition)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1312 (partition_test)

          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:3017 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/home'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • mount_point does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          the setting of more restrictive mount options, which is used as temporary

          directories, installed by other software packages.

          V-204496 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204496r603261_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-021340
          Identities:SV-86689
          V-72065
          CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
          Fix Text:Start the "tmp.mount" service with the following command:

          # systemctl enable tmp.mount

          OR

          Edit the "/etc/fstab" file and ensure the "/tmp" directory is defined in the fstab with a device and mount point.
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:

          Result:false

          Description:The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
          Class:compliance

            • false (check for /tmp)

          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • mount_point does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-204576 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must limit the number of concurrent sessions to 10 for all accounts and/or account types.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204576r877399_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040000
          Identities:V-72217
          SV-86841
          CCI-000054 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-10; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-10.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-10; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-10)
          Description: Operating system management includes the ability to control the number of users and user sessions that utilize an operating system. Limiting the number of allowed users and sessions per user is helpful in reducing the risks related to DoS attacks.

          This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for information system accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by single users via multiple system accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based on mission needs and the operational environment for each system. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to limit the number of concurrent sessions to "10" for all accounts and/or account types.

          Add the following line to the top of the /etc/security/limits.conf or in a ".conf" file defined in /etc/security/limits.d/ :

          * hard maxlogins 10
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7os:def:204576
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-07-040000 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must limit the number of concurrent sessions to 10 for all accounts and/or account types.
          Description:Operating system management includes the ability to control the number of users and user sessions that utilize an operating system. Limiting the number of allowed users and sessions per user is helpful in reducing the risks related to DoS attacks.

          This requirement addresses concurrent sessions for information system accounts and does not address concurrent sessions by single users via multiple system accounts. The maximum number of concurrent sessions should be defined based on mission needs and the operational environment for each system.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less by default)
              • true (limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less for non-default domains)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034600 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less by default
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034600 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:23034600 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '10'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034601 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:true
          Title:limits.conf and limits.d/*.conf:maxlogins is set to 10 or less for non-default domains
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034603 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:23034600 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '10'

          V-204605 - The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must display the date and time of the last successful account logon upon logon.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-204605r858478_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-07-040530
          Identities:SV-86899
          V-72275
          CCI-000052 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-9; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-9.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-9; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-9)
          Description: Providing users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred facilitates user recognition and reporting of unauthorized account use. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to provide users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred by setting the required configuration options in "/etc/pam.d/postlogin".

          Add the following line to the top of "/etc/pam.d/postlogin":

          session required pam_lastlog.so showfailed
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7
          Identifier:2899
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:def:1020
          Result:false
          Title:The Red Hat Enterprise Linux operating system must display the date and time of the last successful account logon upon logon.
          Description:Providing users with feedback on when account accesses last occurred facilitates user recognition and reporting of unauthorized account use.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Check the pam_lastlog configuration of /etc/pam.d/postlogin for the silent option)
            • false (Check the pam_lastlog configuration of /etc/pam.d/postlogin for the showfailed option)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:tst:1021 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Check the pam_lastlog configuration of /etc/pam.d/postlogin for the silent option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:No collected item may match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:obj:2791 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/pam.d'
          • filename must be equal to 'postlogin'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[\s]*[^\s#]+[ \t]+[\[\]\w=]+[ \t]+pam_lastlog\.so[ \t]+([\S \t]+)\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel7:ste:8689900 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^silent[\s]|[\s]silent[\s]|[\s]silent$|^silent$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/pam.d/postlogin'
          • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
          • filename equals 'postlogin'
          • pattern equals '^[\s]*[^\s#]+[ \t]+[\[\]\w=]+[ \t]+pam_lastlog\.so[ \t]+([\S \t]+)\s*$'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'session [default=1] pam_lastlog.so nowtmp showfailed'
          • line equals 'session [default=1] pam_lastlog.so nowtmp showfailed'
          • subexpression equals 'nowtmp showfailed'

          [ true ]

          • path equals '/etc/pam.d'
          • filename equals 'postlogin'
          • pattern equals '^[\s]*[^\s#]+[ \t]+[\[\]\w=]+[ \t]+pam_lastlog\.so[ \t]+([\S \t]+)\s*$'
          • instance equals '2'
          • text equals 'session optional pam_lastlog.so silent noupdate showfailed

          subexpression
